analyzed: jātaka  ti sa nipāta  ki chanda vagga
translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter🔽The Chapter about Desires
The Sambulā Jātaka🔽“Who are you, standing alone in the mountain cave,
your thighs well-knit together?

analyzed: puṭṭhā asi me pāṇi pameyya majjhe
translated: You are measured in my hand,

analyzed: akkhāhi me nāman ca bandhave ca
translated: tell me your name and your relatives.
Illuminating the delightful forest,
frequented by lions and panthers;
What are you, O lovely one,
whose are you, O beautiful one?
I pay homage to you, O blessed one,
I bow to you, O giver of gifts.”
“The son of the king of Kāsi,
known as Sotthisena;
I am his wife Sambulā,

analyzed: evam jānāhi dānava  abhivādemi tam bhante
translated: know this, O giver of gifts;🔽I pay homage to you, O venerable one,
Sambulā bows to you.
The son of the Videha king, O blessed one,
lives in the forest, sick;
I alone attend on him,
afflicted with illness.
I gather forest fruits,
honey and meat from the deer’s cave;
When I bring it, it is his food,
but today he does not accept it.”
“What will you do with the prince,
sick in the forest?
O Sambulā, who is attended by him,
I am your husband.”
“For one who is sorrowful and unfortunate,
what beauty is there for me?
Seek another, good sir,
more beautiful than me.”
“Come, having climbed this mountain,
my wife is four hundred;
You will be the best of them,
accomplishing all desires.
Surely, you who are radiant like the stars,
whatever you desire in your mind;
all that is at your disposal,
enjoy today with me.
If you will not be a queen,
and make Sambala your own;
enough for you to eat in the morning,
in the evening you will have food.”
And that hunter Sattuka,
the dark man-hunter;
not seeing the lord in the forest,
seized Sambala by the arm.
Overcome by the demon,
the hunter with a flesh-eye;
and she came under the power of the hunter,
she lamented only for her husband.
“This is not so much suffering for me,
that a demon should devour me;
but that my husband’s mind
will be otherwise.”
“Surely the gods do not exist,

original: Na hi nūna santi idha lokapālā;🔽Sahasā karontānamasaññatānaṁ,
analyzed: na hi nūna santi idha lokapālā  sahasā karontānam asaññatāna
translated: Surely there are no guardians of the world,🔽Who would not restrain the violent and heedless.
Surely there are no restrainer of the violent and heedless.”
“This is the most excellent and glorious of women,
Calm, composed, with the radiance of a blazing fire.

analyzed: tat ce tuvam rakkhasā ādesi kañña
translated: If you, O demon, were to take this maiden,

original: Muddhā ca hi sattadhā te phaleyya;
analyzed: muddhā ca hi sattadhā te phaleyya
translated: Your head would split into seven pieces.
Do not burn, let go of the one who is devoted to her husband.”
She came to the hermitage,
freed from the man-demon;
Like a bird from a net,
like a deer from a snare.
There she lamented,
the glorious princess;
Weeping, with tears on her face,
not seeing her husband in the forest.
I pay homage to the ascetics and brahmins,
who are perfect in conduct and virtuous;
Not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
I pay homage to the lions and tigers,
and to all the other forest animals;
Not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
I pay homage to the grasses, creepers, and herbs,
to the mountains and forests;
Not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
I praise the one with eyes like blue lotuses,
the one who is like a garland of stars in the night;
not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
I praise the Ganges, which comes down from the Himalayas,
the receiver of all rivers;
not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
I praise the best of mountain kings,
the Himalayas, a heap of rocks;
not seeing the prince,
“I have gone for refuge to you.”
“She has come too far,
the famous daughter of the king.
With whom has she come together?
Who is dearer to her than me?”
“This is what I said then,
having been seized by that enemy.

original: Na me idaṁ tathā dukkhaṁ,🔽yaṁ maṁ khādeyya rakkhaso;
analyzed: na me idam tathā  yam mama khādeyya rakkhasaḥ
translated: This is not so much suffering for me,🔽that a demon might devour me;
but that the young man’s mind
will be otherwise.”

analyzed: corīnam bahubuddhīna  yāsu saccam su dullabha
translated: “Among thieves with much cunning,🔽in whom truth is very hard to find,
the state of a woman is hard to understand,
like a fish in water.”
“May truth protect me thus,
if she will protect me;
I do not recall
anyone dearer to me than you.
By this declaration of the truth,
may your illness be removed.”
“Those seven hundred great elephants,
guarding day and night with raised weapons,
and sixteen hundred archers—
What kind of people do you see, my dear?”
“Adorned with lotus-colored upper robes,
virtuous, with the best of geese,
having heard their well-sung music,

original: Na dāni me tāta tathā yathā pure.
analyzed: na dāni me tāta tathā yathā pure
translated: now I am not like before, dear.
With golden ornaments, well-proportioned,
adorned, like a human goddess,
those women, dear, with faultless limbs,
the khattiya maidens tempt him.

translated: “It is hard to find a woman who is good for a man,

translated: But you have a wife who is good and virtuous,

“If you, having received great wealth,
